Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Enabling research on migrating enterprises to the cloud using GENI

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is tackling challenges associated with migrating enterprise applications to the cloud, including (i) models to predict the impact on performance; (ii) methodologies for assurable policy reconfiguration; and (iii) architectures for cloud data-centers that can provide quality of service guarantees. This project is exploring how GENI can help validate our research, and will use resources including ProtoGENI, Planetlab, and Openflow.

Intellectual Merit: Evaluations using a realistic environment such as GENI will (i) aid in determining models for predicting application performance that make an appropriate trade-off between accuracy and complexity; (ii) enable evaluation of designs for cloud data-center architectures; and (iii) lead to insights on principles for architecting cloud data-centers.

Broader Impact: If successful, the project will have a transformative effect on IT organizations by enabling them to migrate to the cloud. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students on the use of GENI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cloud computing has attractive cost saving potential for IT organizations. However, cloud platforms are known to exhibit much variability in performance, which can lead to poor application response times. By some estimates, businesses such as online retail can lose upto 1% in sales for every 100 ms increase in application response time. While researchers including ourselves are developing techniques to help applications cope with cloud performance variability, validating these techniques has remained a challenge. In this project, we have explored how NSF's GENI infrastructure can help to validate research on cloud computing.

As one specific outcome, we have measured performance variations on two real cloud platforms and shown how these variations may be emulated in a controlled setting on the GENI infrastructure. Some observations include that (i) there is significant short-term performance variability -- while poor performance episodes occur frequently, a large fraction of them only last a few minutes; (ii) in large cloud services with many components, performance problems typically impact only a small subset of components at any time, though all components are impacted at different times.


Emulating performance variability based on these real measurements can in turn enable organizations to understand the performance of their applications if deployed on the cloud, and helps researchers to evaluate the effectiveness of their techniques. Using this emulation approach, we have parameterized a system that we developed that can help cloud applications react to short-term performance variations in the cloud, with the objective of choosing parameters that appropriately trade-off responsiveness and stability. Our evaluations show that when appropriate parameters are chosen, the system strikes a good balance between being responsive to performance variations while being stable. We have also validated performance models that we developed for geo-replicated cloud storage systems. Validating the models required emulating realistic cross data-center delays in controlled settings. 


We disseminated our research to the community through poster sessions, and conference and workshop publications. We extensively participated in the GENI Engineering Conferences, helped guide the requirements for GENI experimenters, and helped test out new GENI features.The project has involved two Ph.D students, who through the project have gained significant experience in conducting research on topics like cloud computing and distributed systems, and who have been able to hone their technical communication skills through writing of scientific papers and workshop and poster presentations.
